content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic's Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
Cox Models = Propotional Hazards Models
Modeling the Hazard Function1Survival analysis methods, such as proportional hazards regression differ from logistic regression by assessing a rate instead of a proportion.
Proportional hazards regression, also called Cox regression, models the incidence or hazard rate, the number of new cases of disease per population at-risk per unit time. If the outcome is death, this is the mortality rate.
The hazard function is the probability that if a person survives to t, they will experience the event in the next instant.
\(\lambda (t|X_{1i}, X_{2i}, ..., X_{ki}) = \lambda _0 (t)exp(\beta_1X_{1i} + \beta_2X_{2i} + ... +\beta_kX_{ki})\)
\(log(\frac{\lambda (t|X_{1i}, X_{2i}, ..., X_{ki})}{\lambda _0 (t)}) = exp(\beta_1X_{1i} + \beta_2X_{2i} + ... +\beta_kX_{ki})\)
\(\lambda (t|X_{1i}, X_{2i}, ..., X_{ki}):\) this is the the hazard function for the ith person at time t,i=1,2,⋯,n. \(\lambda _0 (t):\) this is the baseline hazard function at time t, which is analogous to the intercept term in a multiple regression or logistic regression model.
\(log(\frac{\lambda (t|X_{1i}, X_{2i}, ..., X_{ki})}{\lambda _0 (t)}):\) this is the log of hazard ratio. The ratio of hazard functions can be considered a ratio of risk functions.
There is no particular probability model selected to represent the survival times.
But there is a big assumption: the hazard for any individual is a fixed proportion of the hazard for any other individual. (i.e., proportional hazards). Notice if \(λ_0(t)\) is the hazard function for a subject with all the predictor values equal to zero and \(λ_1(t)\) is the hazard function for a subject with other values for the predictor variables, then the hazard ratio depends only on the predictor variables and not on time t. This assumption means if a covariate doubles the risk of the event on day one, it also doubles the risk of the event on any other day.
Output InterpretationHazard Ratio: similar with odds ratio.
Continuous: A unit increase in X is associated with a YY% increase/decrease in the hazard of (event) on average.
Binary: On average, A has YY% higher/lower hazard of (event) compared to B.
https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat507/node/81/↩
summary:
Cox Models = Propotional Hazards Models
Modeling the Hazard Function1Survival analysis methods, such as proportional hazards regression differ from logistic regression by assessing a rate instead of a proportion.
Proportional hazards regression, also called Cox regression, models the incidence or hazard rate, the number of new cases of disease per population at-risk per unit time. If the outcome is death, this is the mortality rate.
The hazard function is the probability that if a person survives to t, they will experience the event in the next instant.
title: Note11 Cox Models

content:
KM Estimation is a non-parametric estimation of survival function.
when no event times are censored, a non-parametric estimator of S(T) is \(1-F_{n}(t)\), where \(F_{n}(t)\) is the empirical cumulative distribution function.
when some observations are censored, we can estimate S(t) using KM estimation.
Let: \(n_i\) be number of objects at risk of dying at time \(t_i\)
\(d_i\) be number of events that occur at time \(t_i\)
KM estimator \(\hat{S}(t) = \prod_{k=1}^i \frac{n_k - d_k}{n_k}\)
Basic tests for difference in survival curvesWant to test:
\(H_0: S_1(t) = S_2(t)\)
\(H_1: S_1(t) \neq S_2(t)\)
mydat <- matrix(c('d1i','d2i','n1i-d1i','n2i-d2i'),ncol = 2, byrow = T)colnames(mydat) <- c('Group 1', 'Group 2')rownames(mydat) <- c('Died','Survived')mydat## Group 1 Group 2 ## Died "d1i" "d2i" ## Survived "n1i-d1i" "n2i-d2i"Test Statistic:
\(Q = \frac{(\sum w_i (d_{1i} - \hat{e}_{1i}))^2}{\sum w_i ^2 \hat{v}_{1i}}\)where:
\(\hat{e}_{1i} = \frac{n_{1i}d_{1i}}{n_{i}}\)
\(\hat{v}_{1i} = \frac{n_{1i}n_{2i}d_i (n_i - d_i)}{n_i ^2 (n_i - 1)}\)
\(w_i =\) some weighting functing
Tests:
Log-rank: \(w_i = 1\)
Wilcoxon: \(w_i = n_i\)
Tarone-ware: \(w_i = \sqrt{n_i}\)
Peto-Peto: \(w_i = \prod_{i=1}^T (\frac{1-\hat{e}_i}{n_i + 1})\)
summary:
KM Estimation is a non-parametric estimation of survival function.
when no event times are censored, a non-parametric estimator of S(T) is \(1-F_{n}(t)\), where \(F_{n}(t)\) is the empirical cumulative distribution function.
when some observations are censored, we can estimate S(t) using KM estimation.
Let: \(n_i\) be number of objects at risk of dying at time \(t_i\)
\(d_i\) be number of events that occur at time \(t_i\)
title: Note10 Kaplan Meier Estimation

content:
Time to Event DataKeywords: Failure, Lifetime Data, Time-event, Time-to-event-data
Outcome: Time until some events occures -> survival analysis.
In order to measure survival time, need a begining(t=0) and end(t = T).
t=0 is when the clock starts.
t=T is when the event occurs(or censored) + clock stops.
Between this two times(t - T), the subject is said to be “at risk” for the event.
Survival time T is the difference between these two points.
Usually measured in days, months or years.
Question: Time is continuous, why not using linear regression?
Answer: Censoring! If no censoring, you can use it!
CensoringRight Censored(by for the most common)known survival time is greater than some value: T > aLeft Censored(rare)known survival time is less than some value: T < bInterval Censoredknown survival time is within some interval: a < T < bFunctions of Survival TimePDF: f(t)
CDF: F(t) = P(T<t)
Survival Function S(t): S(t) = P(T>t) = 1 - F(t), this is the prob that people survived passed t.
Unconditional probability failure rate f(t): \(f(t) = \lim_{\Delta t\to\ 0}\frac{P(t \leq T \leq t + \Delta t)}{\Delta t}\)
But, subjects who have died before time t are no longer at risk during (t, t + t).
So it make sense to think of a conditional failure rate.
Conditional failure rate: risk of an event occuring at time t, given the subject has survived to time t.
Hazard Function h(t)
\(h(t) = \lim_{\Delta t\to\ 0}\frac{P(t \leq T \leq t + \Delta t | T \geq t)}{\Delta t}\), h(t) > 0, h(t) is not a probability. The hazard function, h(t), is the instantaneous rate at which events occur, given no previous events.
Cumulative Hazard Function H(t)\(H(t) = \int\limits_{0}^{t} h(u) du\)
Relationships between S(t), H(t), h(t), f(t)\(h(t) = - \frac{\partial log(S(t))}{\partial t} = \frac{f(t)}{S(t)}\)
\(H(t) = -log(S(t))\)
\(S(t) = exp(-H(t))\)
\(f(t) = - \frac{\partial S(t)}{\partial t}\)
Comment for Survival DistributionsDistributionh(t)S(t)f(t)Exponential\(\lambda\)\(exp(-\lambda t)\)\(\lambda exp(-\lambda t)\)Weibull$t^{-1} $\(exp(-\lambda t^\alpha)\)\(\alpha \lambda t^{\alpha -1}exp(-\lambda t^\alpha)\)Gompertze\(\theta exp(\alpha t)\)\(exp(\frac{\theta}{\alpha}(1-exp(\alpha t)))\)\(\theta exp(\alpha t)exp(\frac{\theta}{\alpha}(1-exp(\alpha t)))\)Others: Gamma, lognormal, log-logistic, inverse gaussian, Pareto
summary:
Time to Event DataKeywords: Failure, Lifetime Data, Time-event, Time-to-event-data
Outcome: Time until some events occures -> survival analysis.
In order to measure survival time, need a begining(t=0) and end(t = T).
t=0 is when the clock starts.
t=T is when the event occurs(or censored) + clock stops.
Between this two times(t - T), the subject is said to be “at risk” for the event.
title: Note9 Intro to Survival Analysis

title: An example preprint / working paper

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic  Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click  PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let's make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask
 Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides
